Our research aims to address climate change by providing precise irrigation data. This data can help monitor water usage and optimize agricultural yield, particularly in developing countries. By combining irrigation data with precipitation data, we can predict water budgets and improve climate and weather modeling. We have developed a novel irrigation model that uses unsupervised clustering of the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) temporal signatures in conjunction with a precipitation heuristic to identify the months when irrigation peaks for each cropland cluster in a given year. Our model, implemented in the Python package "Irrigation30," generates 30m resolution irrigation predictions for cropland worldwide.

Using a small crowdsourced test set of cropland coordinates and irrigation labels, our model achieved consistency scores exceeding 97% and an accuracy of 92% in a small, geo-diverse test set, outperforming the state-of-the-art NASA-funded GFSAD30 project, which focused on irrigation data in India and Australia.

Understanding global irrigation patterns, including the extent of cropland and water usage, is crucial for various climate science efforts. Irrigated cropland accounts for 70% of global freshwater use (Grafton et al., 2018). As population growth continues, the demand for cropland to meet food needs will increase greenhouse gas emissions (Tillman et al., 2011). This demand will be particularly pronounced in developing countries, where population and consumption growth are disproportionate. Precise irrigation data enables applications such as crop water productivity modeling (Deryng et al., 2016) and global biomass estimation (Mauser et al., 2015).

To address this challenge, we require a precise and accurate understanding of global irrigation usage. However, current data sources are outdated, low-resolution, and potentially inaccurate. Our research develops a machine learning model that estimates irrigation at 30m resolution using the latest satellite and climate datasets from 2017 onwards. We also provide a Python package that allows researchers to utilize our irrigation model and generate irrigation predictions for small regions.

Previous studies have created global irrigation maps at lower resolutions (Meier et al., 2018) or focused on specific regions (Xie et al., 2019). However, these efforts have limitations, such as low resolution or limited geographic scope. The Global Food Security-support Analysis Data @ 30-m (GFSAD30) project provides irrigation labels at 30m resolution, but these products are currently limited to a few regions and are only accessible through visualization (no downloadable content). Our research aims to address these limitations by providing a global, high-resolution irrigation mapping.

Our methodology involves using Sentinel-2 satellite data, which offers a higher revisit frequency than Landsat satellite data. We utilize the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) as a measure of cropland vegetation coverage and healthiness, and climate data, such as precipitation, to inform our analysis. TerraClimate provides global monthly climate data at 2.5 arc minutes, which is approximately 4.2km at the Equator (Abatzoglou et al., 2018).
